subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] How to handle "er" and "ur" in QS
msgSnippet: I agree the ir sound in bird sounds a little different than of the ar in arena (when I say them).  In fact, I wonder if the r semivowel might not just
messageBody:
I agree the 'ir' sound in bird sounds a little different than of the 'ar' in arena (when I say them).  In fact, I wonder if the 'r' semivowel might not just stand on its own: Bay Roar Day.  But that definitely codes more towards my pronunciation than, say, RP.

o

On Sat 2007.11.03, at 23:09, Paul Tremblay wrote:

Responding to my own email. I should have also made clear that I
understand that some members have stated ligatures should only be used
to make appearance look better, not to convey a different meaning.
However, my suggestion would not break this rule, at least for American
English. (I am not sure about other dialects.) In both "arena" and
"bird" you would use an "Ado" followed by a "Roar." In both cases you
could write the letters separately or use ligatures without breaking any
rule. You could also use a ligature for one and not the other and not
break any rule. Only, in the last case, the word might be easier to read.

Thought I needed to add that note of clarity. Time for bed for me.

Paul
Pipe Awl Loll

I agree the 'ir' sound in bird sounds a little different than of the  
'ar' in arena (when I say them).  In fact, I wonder if the 'r'  
semivowel might not just stand on its own: Bay Roar Day.  But that  
definitely codes more towards my pronunciation than, say, RP.

o

> Responding to my own email. I should have also made clear that I
> understand that some members have stated ligatures should only be used
> to make appearance look better, not to convey a different meaning.
> However, my suggestion would not break this rule, at least for  
> American
> English. (I am not sure about other dialects.) In both "arena" and
> "bird" you would use an "Ado" followed by a "Roar." In both cases you
> could write the letters separately or use ligatures without  
> breaking any
> rule. You could also use a ligature for one and not the other and not
> break any rule. Only, in the last case, the word might be easier to  
> read.
>
> Thought I needed to add that note of clarity. Time for bed for me.
>
> Paul
> Pipe Awl Loll
>
>
